Triggering Event: A middle-aged woman, her shift at the retail store nearing its end, feels her irritation grow as she watches a young couple carelessly discard clothing they'd tried on but didn't buy. She sighs inwardly, knowing it's her job to pick up after them once they leave.

But why does it always happen on Fridays? It's like everyone who works here wants to go home early, leaving us to deal with all the late-night shoppers. And don't even get me started on how much I hate having to clean up after other people's messes—like, seriously, couldn't these people see that they're making a huge mess and take responsibility for cleaning up after themselves? I mean, come on! Don't you know that our store policy requires you to pick up after yourself? But then I start thinking about how many times I've had to deal with this exact situation before. Like, seriously, how do some people not learn their lesson? Doesn't anyone remember that when you try clothes on and decide not to buy them, you need to throw away your trash? It's not that hard! Why do I always have to be the one to remind them that they left their dirty clothes behind? Can't they see that they're making it harder for us to help the next customer if they don't put their stuff back where it belongs? I guess what really gets under my skin is when these people act like they have nothing better to do than to make my life more difficult. Like, are they just trying to be annoying? Do they think it's funny to leave their trash

Triggering Event: He arrived at the hospital, his scrubs already wrinkled from hours of wear. A young nurse he'd trained months ago breezed past him, chattering into her phone about plans for a night out. He felt a pang of irritation as she ignored their overlap in patient care, leaving him to explain yet again why Mr. Thompson's new medication wasn't on the system.
Generated Assessment: He fucking couldn't believe it! She was supposed to cover his shift today, but instead she was chatting with some random guy on her phone while ignoring him completely. It just didn't make sense - they were colleagues, after all. But fuck it, this is what happens when you're an asshole like me. First off, she shouldn't have been so busy. We both knew how much we had on our plates right now. Then there's the fact that she's supposed to be learning from someone who's been around the block a few times, so it makes sense that she'd want to learn from me. And come on, she shouldn't be talking to anyone else while she's working? That's basic professionalism, right? But nope, she just went ahead and did whatever she wanted. I mean, she could've been having a bad day, maybe she was dealing with family stuff. But fuck, she shouldn't act like that because she doesn't get paid enough anyway. Yeah, sure, let's ignore the whole "we work together" thing since it clearly doesn't matter. So yeah, she definitely shouldn't have been talking to that random guy. Shouldn't be doing anything other than focusing on her job, especially if she's new. She probably thinks she can treat everyone like shit because she's got the same title as me. Well, newsflash, girl, you don't know squat about being a real nurse unless you're actually doing your fucking job

Triggering Event: She pulls over the speeding driver, a young man barely out of his teens. As she approaches his window, he smirks and says, "You're cute when you're angry."
Generated Assessment: She's 35, I'm 25. He's a junior in college, she's in her mid-30s. No one's going to take this lightly. They're both driving aggressively, but I'm the one who's really speeding. He was doing 95 mph in a 65 zone, and she pulled him over for that alone. She wasn't even trying to be nice; she just kept repeating, "Sir, you need to pull over now." He didn't try to hide it, either - he smirked the whole time, like he knew he was being busted for something stupid. She seemed annoyed by his attitude, though. When he said, "You're cute when you're angry," I could tell she wanted to shut him down. But instead, she tried to keep it professional, saying, "Please stay in your vehicle." Even then, she looked like she was struggling to maintain her composure. It was clear that she didn't want to give him any slack.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, wearing his faded name tag, watches as a young couple he'd helped earlier in the day leaves the store, laughing and holding hands. He feels a pang of shame, remembering how he snapped at them when they asked for help finding an item, assuming they were wasting his time. No one else seems to notice or care about his slip-up, but he can't shake the feeling that he's let himself down once again.
Generated Assessment: This is insane! I'm just so upset. It's like I don't even deserve to be here. The way I treated those people was so horrible, and no one cares. They probably think I'm such an asshole. I feel so stupid because I assumed they were trying to waste my time, and now I'm acting like this? This is all my fault. I really have no right to be here. I shouldn't even be allowed to breathe. It makes me wonder why anyone would want to come back into this place after what happened. I've been coming here for years, and it never bothered me before. But now, I realize I don't belong here. I'm a terrible person who doesn't deserve to be around decent people like that couple. My feelings are so accurate; I'm just too weak to admit it. No one should ever see me again. I shouldn't be working here anyway. I'm just a burden to everyone. This whole experience has made me realize how much of a loser I am. If I wasn't here, everything would be better. People wouldn't treat me like shit, and I wouldn't make them feel so bad. I'm going to go home and lock myself in my room. Maybe then I'll stop bothering everyone. And hopefully, no one will miss me.

Triggering Event: He noticed her favorite mug, still unwashed from yesterday's coffee, in the sink. His breath caught as grief surged like a tide, drowning him once more.
Generated Assessment: He just can't seem to get over it, can he? It's been two years since she left us, but every day feels like an eternity. I catch myself thinking about what could have been if only things had turned out differently. But then again, maybe they did turn out differently, and that's exactly why we're no longer together. You know how sometimes you focus so much on one thing that everything else fades into the background? Yeah, that’s me right now. I’m stuck on this one thought, unable to let go. It’s like my brain is playing a loop of “what ifs” that keeps me up at night. Every time I try to push those thoughts away, another wave comes crashing back. It’s exhausting, but somehow I keep coming back for more. Sometimes when I see something like his favorite mug, even though it means nothing to anyone else, I feel like I'm drowning in memories. The way it looks, the smell of coffee it must hold, all these emotions come flooding back. And yet, it's just an old mug—why does it mean so much to me? My mind won’t stop jumping between good times and bad. I remember the laughter, the late-night conversations, the quiet moments when it was just us. But there are also the tears, the fights, the pain. My brain seems to be trying to balance both sides, making it impossible to move forward. Maybe I’m holding onto too many things, but it

Triggering Event: At the company's team-building retreat, he noticed her laughing with another colleague at the barbecue, their bodies slightly touching as they shared stories of their weekend. He felt a pang in his chest when she looked up at him and smiled, but it was the other man who got to walk her back to her cabin that night.
Generated Assessment: As I watched them share laughter over drinks, I couldn't help but feel an overwhelming sense of resentment. The way they seemed to connect over every topic, effortlessly gliding into conversations that made me feel like an outsider, was infuriating. It wasn't just the physical closeness between them; the way they leaned into each other while talking made my heart ache with jealousy. I saw how they exchanged playful jabs, their body language open and carefree, and I felt trapped by the impossibility of ever being more than a friend. The fact that she chose someone else for her weekend getaway, someone who didn't have to pretend to be interested in our work projects, only added to my frustration.

Triggering Event: As he sat at his desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard, he glanced up at the framed photo on his monitor: a younger him with his wife and daughter, laughing on a beach vacation. His eyes welled up as he remembered that was the last trip they'd taken together before the divorce, five years ago today. He sighed heavily, his sadness palpable in the quiet office.

The coffee machine is brewing, its gurgle breaking through the stillness, yet no one else notices—no one cares. The clock ticks away, each second a reminder of what could've been if only he had stayed. Five years gone, yet it feels like an eternity since that fateful day when everything fell apart. The image on his screen, a memory he thought he'd long buried, now taunts him. A young couple, carefree and happy, smiling in front of a tropical backdrop—a stark contrast to his current reality. How could someone so oblivious to the world’s problems laugh and smile? It’s infuriating to think about how much time has passed since the last time he felt truly connected to someone. Now, every moment is spent alone, drowning in self-pity. Even the words on the screen seem hollow, lacking meaning as he stares blankly at the cursor. The silence around him is oppressive, weighing heavily on his chest. Every breath feels forced, every movement mechanical. He can’t shake the feeling that he’s running out of time, that every tick of the clock marks down the moments lost forever. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A middle-aged woman, married and dedicated to her teaching career, is walking home from school in the dimming twilight. She often takes this route, feeling safe despite the growing darkness as winter approaches. Tonight, however, she hears faint footsteps behind her, echoing hers. Her heart begins to race as she tries to convince herself it's just another early evening walker. But when she turns her head slightly, there's no one there. The footsteps continue, unyielding. She dares not look back again, quickening her pace, keys clutched tightly between her fingers like a makeshift weapon. Every shadow seems to stretch and twist, threatening. Home feels miles away.
Generated Assessment: She is convinced that someone is following her. What if they are just two people who happen to be going in the same direction? It doesn't necessarily mean anything, but she can't shake off the feeling of being watched. The streets seem darker than usual, and every noise makes her jump.

Triggering Event: After another sleepless night, she rushed to school, realizing at the last moment she'd forgotten her lesson plans. As she hurried through the bustling hallway, students' chatter echoing off the lockers, a fellow teacher stopped her. "You okay? You look tired." She forced a smile, but felt her heart race as anxiety surged. "Just forgot my plans," she replied, clutching her empty folder.
Generated Assessment: She was already stressed about meeting deadlines, so why did this happen again? That teacher seemed genuinely concerned, but what if they were just trying to make me feel worse? She didn't mean anything by it; it's probably just an awkward morning greeting. I'm just so overwhelmed with work right now. It's really frustrating when people say things like that. They don't understand how much stress I have. ## Step 1: Identify the trigger Identify the triggering event that led to the distorted thought. In this case, the teacher’s comment triggered the distorted thinking. ## Step 2: Analyze the thoughts Analyze the thoughts generated after the trigger. The student is assuming that the teacher’s behavior concerns them personally, without considering alternative explanations (e.g., the teacher might be having a bad day too). This shows personalization, where the individual assumes that others’ actions are directed towards them instead of recognizing more likely scenarios. ## Step 3: Evaluate the emotions Evaluate the emotions expressed in the response. The student feels frustrated, overwhelmed, and annoyed, indicating a negative emotional state. These emotions seem to stem from the perceived intrusion into their personal space, which reinforces the distorted thought. ## Step 4: Assess the conclusion Assess whether the conclusion drawn from the analysis accurately represents the distortion.
